3668334197.resolved_title: Romance, Politics, and Ecological Damage: The Saga of Sable Island’s Wild Horses
3668334197.excerpt: They’ve roamed free for hundreds of years, but is that freedom harming the ecosystem they call home? This article is also available in audio format. Listen now, download, or subscribe to “Hakai Magazine Audio Edition” through your favorite podcast app.

1.caption: Horses were first left on Sable Island, Nova Scotia, in the 1700s, and their descendants have roamed free ever since. These wild horses have behaved as invasive species have the world over—altering the natural ecosystem. But unlike other introduced species, such as rats, starlings, or zebra mussels, they’ve been deemed as “naturalized” and are treated more as wildlife than the feral animals they are. Photo by Julie Marshall/Shutterstock

2.caption: Sable Island is a 40-kilometer-long sandbar 161 kilometers off the coast of Nova Scotia. Map data by ArcGIS

3.caption: The horses of Sable Island share their home with the world’s largest breeding colony of gray seals. Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

4.caption: It is unclear how many horses were first landed at Sable Island in the 1700s, but today’s population is somewhere between 500 and 600. Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

5.caption: The charisma of Sable Island’s very photogenic wild horses has furthered their existence on the island. When the Canadian government decided to remove the horses in the 1960s over concerns of animal welfare and the ecological damage the horses might be doing, public outcry reversed the decision. Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

6.caption: Parks Canada’s Fences in the Sand study is using exclosures to observe what happens to the natural ecosystem when horses are excluded. Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

7.caption: If horses didn’t live on Sable Island, would people care much about this small spit of shifting sand? Photo courtesy of Parks Canada

2559761535.resolved_title: Gulf of Thailand dog rescued by oil rig worker after it's found swimming 135 MILES off the coast
2559761535.excerpt: Dog is rescued after it's found swimming 135 MILES out at sea: Oil rig workers pluck pooch from Gulf of Thailand - and have no idea how it got there This is the incredible moment a dog was rescued after being found swimming in the Gulf of Thailand - 135 miles from shore.

1.caption: A dog has been rescued after being found swimming in the Gulf of Thailand - 135 miles from shore. The exhausted female was lifted to safety by workers using a rope as she lay dripping wet

2.caption: The brown Aspin hides among the rusty bars of the oil rig after being found swimming 135 miles off the coast of Thailand

3.caption: The dog lies on the metal grates of the rig with the rope still fastened around her body

4.caption: Workers from the oil rig in the Gulf of Thailand pet the dog after they saved her but mystery surrounds how she got there

5.caption: Oil rig worker Khon Vitisak, who rescued the dog, offers her a bucket of water which she readily accepts

6.caption: The dog was rescued in the Gulf of Thailand, which is south of the country and to the west of Cambodia and Vietnam

7.caption: She looks out from the oil rig deck over the vast Gulf of Thailand sea that she was found swimming in

8.caption: The team on board the oil rig stand with the dog they saved and have put a lei of flowers around her neck

9.caption: The Aspin looks up as she doses following the marathon swim through the choppy ocean

10.caption: One of the oil rig workers comforts the dog by stroking her paw as she rests on a concrete floor

11.caption: The dog, which was not given a name, looks at its new temporary home in a cage on the rig

12.caption: The tired mutt looks relaxed as she lies next to her makeshift cage on the drilling platform

13.caption: Oil rig workers crouch with the pup. The animal had lost a lot of body water, but the men fed her vitamins and minerals and her health improved

14.caption: She stayed on the drilling platform for two nights while a special cage was welded together

15.caption: The pooch was lifted by crane on to a passing oil tanker which was passing through the area yesterday

16.caption: The dog wears a lei of flowers and smiles at the camera from the back of a car as it returns to the mainland

3347145698.excerpt: The Elephant Ethogram is a uniquely detailed catalogue, or library, of the behavior and communication of African savanna elephants (Loxodonta africana).

3465635294.resolved_title: Are We on the Verge of Chatting with Whales?

1.caption: Researchers are hoping to decipher the communications of sperm whales. Photo by Amanda Cotton/Project CETI

2.caption: Sperm whales dive deep into the ocean and communicate over long distances via a system of clicks. Photo by Amanda Cotton/Project CETI

2355713234.given_title: Herschel, the Very Hungry Sea Lion | Hakai Magazine
2355713234.resolved_title: Herschel, the Very Hungry Sea Lion
2355713234.excerpt: It’s dangerous to blame the decline of one species on a single predator. We humans like to do it anyway. This article is also available in audio format. Listen now, download, or subscribe to “Hakai Magazine Audio Edition” through your favorite podcast app.

1.caption: Illustration by Mark Garrison

2.caption: The Hiram M. Chittenden Locks connect Puget Sound with Lake Washington in Washington State. Photo by Danita Delimont/Alamy Stock Photo

3.caption: In Seattle, Herschel’s gluttony became the stuff of legends. Detail of a photo by Grant Haller, Post-Intelligencer

4.caption: Fake Willy, one of the failed California sea lion deterrents employed at Hiram M. Chittenden Locks, went missing for years before turning up outside a Mexican restaurant in Seattle. Locks staff asked for Fake Willy’s return, and now the sculpture stands in front of the visitor center during summer months. The rest of the year, it’s stored on this platform. Photo by Katharine Gammon

5.caption: These days, visitors may see salmon passing the viewing window at the Hiram M. Chittenden Locks, though they’re not likely to spot a single steelhead. Photo by Danita Delimont/Alamy Stock Photo

6.caption: Illustration by Mark Garrison

8.caption: Hondo and two other sea lions captured at the Hiram M. Chittenden Locks are loaded onto a FedEx plane in Seattle to be exiled to Sea World in Orlando, Florida, in 1996. Photo courtesy of the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife

9.caption: Herschel, the infamous California sea lion, rests on a navigation buoy in Shilshole Bay in Seattle, near the Hiram M. Chittenden Locks, circa 1984. Photo by the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

3220589110.resolved_title: Keeping Watch Over Seabirds at the World’s Edge
3220589110.excerpt: In Alaska, one of the longest-running and most comprehensive seabird monitoring projects is equal parts tedium, adventure, truth, and beauty. January 5, 2021 | 5,900 words, about 29 minutes This article is also available in audio format.

1.caption: Marc Romano, biologist for the Bering Sea and Chukchi Sea units of the Alaska Maritime National Wildlife Refuge, scans for seabirds near St. Matthew Island, in the Bering Sea. St. Matthew and neighboring islands are critical nesting habitat for a dozen species of seabirds. Photo by Nathaniel Wilder

2.caption: The Milos Reefer, a Greek cargo vessel, wrecked off the northeast coast of St. Matthew Island, Alaska, in 1989.

3.caption: Brie Drummond

4.caption: Seabirds, including common murres and thick-billed murres, nest each summer on difficult-to-access cliffs and sea stacks like these on the northwestern coast of St. Matthew Island, in the Bering Sea.

5.caption: Map data by OpenStreetMap via ArcGIS

6.caption: Biologists in a skiff from the Tiĝlax̂ survey for birds inside a circle of towering cliffs on the northwest coast of St. Matthew Island.

8.caption: Drummond, DeGange, and nesting murres on Hall Island with St. Matthew Island in the distance.

9.caption: Thick-billed murres protect their eggs by facing toward the cliffs they nest on, preventing the eggs from rolling, or being kicked, off the ledge.

10.caption: Seabirds fly between the islands and sea stacks off the northwest coast of St. Matthew Island.

12.caption: A black-legged kittiwake guards its chick.

13.caption: The northern tip of Hall Island, part of the Alaska Maritime National Wildlife Refuge in the Bering Sea.

3362922745.given_title: The Gull Next Door | Hakai Magazine
3362922745.excerpt: Your obnoxious neighbor or just a misunderstood, displaced seabird? This article is also available in audio format. Listen now, download, or subscribe to “Hakai Magazine Audio Edition” through your favorite podcast app.

1.caption: Gulls can seem ubiquitous in cities, but it hasn’t always been this way. Photo by John Waters/Minden Pictures

2.caption: Gulls at home in urban environments—such as this lesser black-backed gull hovering over a park in Bath, England—often travel with precisely timed accuracy to capitalize on human food sources. Photo by Nick Upton/Alamy Stock Photo

3.caption: The carving Raven and Seagull Releasing Daylight, by Nuu-chah-nulth artist Tim Paul, captures a story of how the birds grapple over Seagull’s hoarding of daylight. Photo courtesy of Steinbrueck Native Gallery

4.caption: With their reliable additions of food, open landfills such as this one in Pitsea, England, are a draw for many urban birds, including gulls. Photo by Terry Whittaker/2020Vision/Minden Pictures

5.caption: A glaucous-winged gull hangs out in the busy Inner Harbour area of Victoria, British Columbia. Photo by Marc Bruxelle RF/Alamy Stock Photo

6.caption: Despite their seeming affinity for human food, gulls, like this glaucous-winged gull, have a varied diet of natural foods including fish and marine invertebrates, such as clams or crabs. Photo by Bill Gozansky/Alamy Stock Photo

7.caption: A newly hatched glaucous-winged gull in its nest on Mandarte Island, British Columbia. Photo by Jack Chapman/Minden Pictures

8.caption: This lesser black-backed gull, sporting a GPS tracker and ID leg bands, is part of the urban gull project at the University of Bristol, England. Photo courtesy of Anouk Spelt and Cara Williamson

9.caption: Human activities, including farming, have created new food sources for gulls. Photo by Gary K. Smith/Minden Pictures

10.caption: In many coastal cities, gulls are starting to view rooftops as viable nesting habitat. This herring gull had its chick in a nest built atop a chimney in Whitby, England. Photo by Gary K. Smith/Minden Pictures

At 3 years old, they were in the prime of their vigor, ferocity and buoyant, pencil-limbed indifference to gravity.

3692228057.excerpt: The naked mole rat may not be much to look at, but it has much to say. The wrinkled, whiskered rodents, which live, like many ants do, in large, underground colonies, have an elaborate vocal repertoire. They whistle, trill and twitter; grunt, hiccup and hiss.

3807140033.given_title: How Octopus Arms Bypass the Brain
3807140033.resolved_title: How Octopus Arms Bypass the Brain
3807140033.excerpt: Octopuses' sucker-covered arms can act as if they contain partly independent mini brains. Each arm gathers sensory information to drive its own movements—and even those of other arms—without consulting major brain regions.

3761887583.excerpt: The geographer Jared Diamond has called domestication the worst mistake humans ever made. He blames domestication for the rise of monoculture, which he says leads to a larger, more sedentary human population in which disease can spread rapidly.

4001187630.given_title: Why Insects Are Attracted to Light at Night
4001187630.resolved_title: Why Insects Are Attracted to Light at Night
4001187630.excerpt: The first humans to sit around campfires probably observed a strange example of animal behavior that continues to perplex people today. They would have seen insects that emerge from the night and begin to endlessly circle the artificially produced light source, with sometimes fatal results.

2425149554.given_title: The Story of Dyngo, a War Dog Brought Home From Combat
2425149554.resolved_title: The Story of Dyngo, a War Dog Brought Home From Combat

In front of me was a large dog, snapping his jaws so hard that his teeth gave a loud clack with each bark. His eyes were locked on me, desperate for the toy I was holding.

1.caption: The author with Dyngo in Washington, D.C. Several of his teeth are missing or ground down now. “Still, no toy I give him survives for long,” she says.

2.caption: In War Dogs, Rebecca Frankel offers a riveting mix of on-the-ground reporting, her own hands-on experiences in the military working dog world, and a look at the science of dogs' special abilities-from their amazing noses and powerful jaws to their enormous sensitivity to the emotions of their human companions.

1.caption: PLANET OBSERVER / UIG / AGEFOTOSTOCK; Vemaps.com

2.caption:
A previously unknown species of dwarf lemur inhabits the Lost Forest. During the expedition researchers captured the nocturnal, tree-dwelling animal to examine it and take hair and blood samples for analysis, then released it. 
    
    
      Noel Rowe

3.caption:
In the rainforest an expedition member holds the shell of a Helicophanta, or land snail. There are dozens of Malagasy chameleon species, from large to small. They amount to nearly half of all those that are known to exist in the world. 
    
    
      Noel Rowe

1.caption:
Navy Diver Second Class Michael Gerstel rewards a bottlenose dolphin during an annual training exercise in Little Creek, Virginia.

                        Bruce Cummins / U.S. NAVY

2.caption:
Hull Technician Fireman Stefan Gingerich gives positive reinforcement during a mine countermeasure exercise in the Pacific. 
                        Jennifer A. Villalovos / U.S. NAVY

3.caption:
The Navy unit uses the marine mammals because they can locate and mark mines using their built-in sonar capabilities. 
                        Rafael Martie / U.S. NAVY

4.caption:
Handler Eric Kenas uses hand gestures with a dolphin. The Navy has trained marine mammals, including belugas like Noc, for 50 years. 
                        Pierre G. Georges / U.S. NAVY

5.caption:
Michael Gerstel works with a cetacean assigned to the Marine Mammal Company of Explosive Ordnance Disposal Mobile Unit.
                        Bruce Cummins / U.S. NAVY

6.caption:
Sam Ridgway deployed whales in the Navy Marine Mammal Program. “They come to think of us as family,” he says. “And that’s the reason they stay with  us.” 
                         Robert Benson

7.caption:
Navy harbor-patrol sea lion, San Diego.
                         Bob Houlihan / U.S. Navy

8.caption:
Another dolphin gets training with the unit’s Christopher Burgess in 2013 in Point Loma, California, before a nighttime exercise. 
                        Joshua Scott / U.S. NAVY

9.caption:
Navy mine-detection dolphin, Persian Gulf.
                        Brien Aho / U.S. Navy

11.caption:
Dolphin marking a practice mine, undisclosed location.
                        U.S. Navy

3282278093.excerpt: At a steady trot, wolves can go 20 miles without breaking stride and cover 50 miles in a day. Their long thin legs move with the inevitability of bicycle wheels, with the rear foot landing in the exact spot just vacated by the front foot and the rest of the wolf flowing along.

1.caption:
New members of the Lassen pack, 2-month-old pups frolic with year-old siblings. In 2020, the pack’s founding female bore another litter, of five pups, while one of her daughters gave birth to four.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

2.caption:
A wolf’s paw print is similar to that of a dog, though generally larger. Finding one near a livestock carcass doesn’t mean Canis lupus was the killer: It is also a keen scavenger.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

3.caption:
Left, Laudon works in his trailer, which serves as field quarters for him and his canine companion, Sammie. Right, his mini fridge doubles as cold storage for vials of blood collected from briefly captured wolves. Here, samples from an alpha female.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

4.caption:
Trail cameras typically are set in the ground or in trees. Combining camera sightings and data from telemetry collars, Laudon has followed the movements of the Lassen pack across 500 square miles.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

5.caption:
A 14-month-old male pup, known as LAS13M, is likely heading toward other wolves in the meadow. He left the pack last year and has been living in Oregon.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

6.caption:
Left, Deana Clifford, a veterinary epidemiologist, works with Laudon, safe-capturing and examining wolves for signs of disease. Right, she adjusts a GPS-equipped radio collar, detectable on the ground up to 20 miles away.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

7.caption: Map: Guilbert Gates; Map Sources: Oregon Fish and  Wildlife, California Department of Fish and Wildlife

8.caption:
A wolf shares a meadow with a herd in Lassen County. Ranchers say the mere presence of wolves stresses cattle, reducing their weight gain—and, thus, profits.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

9.caption:
Field biologist Kent Laudon wields an antenna and a radio receiver in Lassen County to track collared wolves. He sees a place for them in the wild—and also appreciates ranchers’ concerns.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

10.caption:
Although rancher Wallace Roney had one confirmed wolf kill in his herd so far, he believes that depredations will intensify as the wolf population increases.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

11.caption:
George Edward Knox III, Roney’s grandson, displays a photograph of the remains of a slaughtered calf, from one of his family’s herds, that he says was killed by a wolf.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

12.caption:
Some of Roney’s cattle graze in an enclosure marked by colored flags. The movable fencing, called fladry, deters wolves, but Roney notes it requires upkeep and extra labor.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

13.caption:
Kent Laudon and Sammie sit at the edge of what he calls “Pup Meadow,” hoping to spot wolves at the end of the day.

    
    
      Morgan Heim

14.caption:
The Lassen County pack had expanded from one wolf to 15 in five years. Such growth points both to the success of the species in the Golden State and to continued controversy.
    
    
      Morgan Heim

3707908652.given_title: The Fatal Error of an Ancient, HIV-Like Virus
3707908652.resolved_title: The Fatal Error of an Ancient, HIV-Like Virus
3707908652.excerpt: Many, many millions of years ago, an HIV-like virus wriggled its way into the genome of a floofy, bulgy-eyed lemur, and got permanently stuck. Trapped in a cage of primate DNA, the virus could no longer properly copy itself or cause life-threatening disease.

3698124728.resolved_title: Purring Is a Love Language No Human Can Speak
3698124728.excerpt: Some cats do it, but others can’t—and researchers still don’t fully understand why. On the not-so-infrequent nights when I’m plagued by insomnia, no combination of melatonin, weighted blankets, and white noise will do.

3803481989.resolved_title: A ‘Distinctly Human’ Trait That Might Actually Be Universal
3803481989.excerpt: Disgust is surprisingly common across nature. Eleven years ago, on the remote Japanese island of Kojima, a female macaque walked backwards into a stray heap of primate poop, glanced down at her foot, and completely flipped her lid.

3818254621.given_title: There’s Something Odd About the Dogs Living at Chernobyl
3818254621.resolved_title: There’s Something Odd About the Dogs Living at Chernobyl
3818254621.excerpt: Pets left behind when people fled the disaster in 1986 seem to have seeded a unique population. In the spring of 1986, in their rush to flee the radioactive plume and booming fire that burned after the Chernobyl power plant exploded, many people left behind their dogs.

4012912231.given_title: How First Contact With Whale Civilization Could Unfold
4012912231.resolved_title: How First Contact With Whale Civilization Could Unfold
4012912231.excerpt: If we can learn to speak their language, what should we say? One night last winter, over drinks in downtown Los Angeles, the biologist David Gruber told me that human beings might someday talk to sperm whales.

2367445517.excerpt: Filmmaker Sam Green was just about to fly out of Columbus, Ohio when his friend offered to make a quick detour. “She asked if I wanted to see a little pet cemetery that's across the street from the airport,” Green told The Atlantic.

3637762244.resolved_title: Animal magic: why intelligence isn’t just for humans
3637762244.excerpt: How do you spot an optimistic pig? This isn’t the setup for a punchline; the question is genuine, and in the answer lies much that is revealing about our attitudes to other minds – to minds, that is, that are not human.

1.caption: Illustration: Valero Doval

2304625056.given_title: How to be human: the man who was raised by wolves
2304625056.resolved_title: How to be human: the man who was raised by wolves
2304625056.excerpt: The first time Marcos Rodríguez Pantoja ever heard voices on the radio, he panicked. “Fuck,” he remembers thinking, “those people have been inside there a long time!” It was 1966, and Rodríguez woke from a nap to the sound of voices.

3351490684.given_title: The elephant vanishes: how a circus family went on the run
3351490684.resolved_title: The elephant vanishes: how a circus family went on the run
3351490684.excerpt: One day in late September 2020, the Kludsky family – Yvonne, a slim, blond woman in her 60s, her husband, George, who is over 80 but still fit and strong, and their son Martyn – led their elephant up a ramp into the 10-metre trailer that constituted her second home.

3848552222.given_title: Sleeping beauties: the evolutionary innovations that wait millions of years
3848552222.resolved_title: Sleeping beauties: the evolutionary innovations that wait millions of years to come good
3848552222.excerpt: What are the most successful organisms on the planet? Some people might think of apex predators like lions and great white sharks. For others, insects or bacteria might come to mind. But few would mention a family of plants that we see around us every day: grasses.

2663548782.excerpt: In Ísafjörður, the capital of Iceland’s remote Westfjords region, a Lutheran pastor compared eiderdown to cocaine. “I sometimes think that we are like the coca farmers in Colombia,” he said. “We [the down harvesters] get a fraction of the price when the product hits the streets of Tokyo.

2678204591.resolved_title: How a 6,000-Year-Old Dog Cancer Spread Around the World
2678204591.excerpt: High in the Himalayas, a heavy-coated dog trots behind the hem of a Buddhist monk’s robes. On the streets of Panama City, another dog collapses into a sliver of shade, escaping the heat of the midday sun. On their bodies a cancer grows.
